Award.AwardTitle: COMPACT MODULI AND VECTOR BUNDLES CONFERENCE
Award.AbstractNarration:
A conference on Compact Moduli and Vector Bundles, which will be held at the University of Georgia during October 20-24, 2010, will allow an exchange of ideas in these interrelated subjects. The topics will include the moduli space of stable varieties and pairs, including stable curves but also with a special emphasis on the higher-dimensional case, and the vector bundles on compact moduli spaces, with a special emphasis on conformal block bundles.

The objective of the conference is to bring together and strengthen an international community of algebraic geometers including many young people -- graduate students, postdocs and junior faculty -- as well as established researchers for discussing the progress achieved during last few years and
to produce cross-fertilization between several major fields of study and spark new ideas and cooperation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is an exciting moment in the crossroads of the theories of vector bundles and moduli.    With the objective of bringing together and strengthening the international community of algebraic geometers working in these areas, we held the conference Compact Moduli and Vector Bundles,  at the University of Georgia from October 21 to 24, 2010. Twenty experts from across the US and abroad spoke at the conference. The focus of their talks included the current state of the art on the birational geometry of compact moduli spaces of curves and higher-dimensional stable varieties and pairs, as well as recent developments related to vector bundles on them, with an emphasis on conformal block bundles.


The first major topic of focus at the conference was  compact moduli spaces of curves, and of stable varieties and pairs. Moduli spaces of curves occupy a very special position in the landscape of algebraic varieties.   As moduli spaces, they give insight into the study of smooth curves and their degenerations and serve as models for moduli of higher dimensional varieties. As varieties, they have a rich geometric structure with a flavor that is on the one hand intricately combinatorial, and on the other hand a fertile ground for the application of the rapidly expanding techniques of birational geometry and the minimal model program. Moduli of stable varieties and pairs originated in the 1989 paper of Kollár and Shepherd-Barron, and through the years the theory was developed and expanded to many important cases by Kollár, Alexeev, Hassett, Kovács, Hacking, Keel, Tevelev, Viehweg, and others. Recently, many new explicit compactifications of this type have been discovered, and there is a major book-writing project underway. The last conference on this subject was in December of 2004 at the American Institute of Mathematics. Our conference provided a forum for discussing the progress achieved since that time.

The second major topic addressed at our conference was vector bundles on compact moduli spaces, and in particular, conformal block bundles. These bundles originated in physics in the 1970s.  Conformal blocks played a central role in the proof of the famous Verlinde formula by Beauville-Laszlo-Sorger, Faltings, Szenes, Labourie and others. Many mathematicians have continued to work on this subject and there are many recent papers  by Looijenga, Varchenko, Ueno's school, and many others. Recent new development have recast the subject as being relevant for problems about the birational geometry of the moduli space of curves. 


In addition to the 20 speakers, there were more than 80 conference participants,  and we were able to provide financial support for 64 of them. Of this number,  44 were early career algebraic geometers.  In addition to financial support, we also provided career outreach to the young people. We asked older postdocs and young faculty to help us mentor the graduate students and young postdocs by introducing themselves, finding out the student's research interest, and introducing them to other people at the conference who might share similar interests.  The idea was to try to lessen the intimidation barrier for graduate students to meet senior people.  We matched 12 postdocs with 36 graduate students. 

We are currently working on a proceedings volume in the American Mathematical Society Contemporary Math series with editors Valery Alexeev,  Angela Gibney,  Elham Izadi, Janos Kollár, and Eduard Looijenga.
